description: Tech jobs, layoffs, work patterns, and labor-market claims (US + Europe, 2025–present)

cases.claim: Tech layoffs in 2025 exceeded 120,000 globally, and 2026 YTD exceeded 20,000 (as tracked by Layoffs.fyi).
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Layoffs.fyi year total for 2025: 123,941 tech layoffs (tracker total).
Layoffs.fyi 2026 YTD total shown on tracker: 24,818 layoffs (as of Feb 8, 2026).

cases.claim: Remote workers are 13% more productive than office workers (general claim across roles).
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Large randomized hybrid-work experiment found no negative effects on performance reviews or promotions (not a universal +13% boost).
Evidence reviews find WFH productivity effects are mixed and context-dependent (not a universal +13%).

cases.claim: AI will replace 30% of current jobs by 2030.
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: WEF Future of Jobs 2025: disruption ~22% by 2030; 170M created vs 92M displaced; net +78M (not '30% jobs replaced').
ILO framing: higher share of jobs transformed vs fully replaced; high-risk share smaller than broad '30% jobs' claim.

cases.claim: Venture capital funding rebounded in 2025 (vs 2024), led by US AI mega-rounds; Europe also improved vs 2024.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Crunchbase: ~$425B invested in 2025; +30% YoY vs ~$328B in 2024; driven by big AI rounds.
European venture reporting shows improvement vs 2024 (directional; varies by stage/measure).

cases.claim: Software engineer salaries declined by 10% in 2025 across the US and Europe.
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Compensation trend reporting shows variation by level/company; not a broad -10% decline across markets.
Germany salary survey indicates mixed outcomes by role/specialty rather than blanket -10% declines.

cases.claim: Most large employers mandated full-time return to office by 2025.
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Hybrid remains the dominant policy category among tracked employers; full-time office is a minority.
Work Trend reporting continues to describe hybrid reality rather than universal full RTO.

cases.claim: Independent/gig workers surpassed 70 million in the US by 2025 (definition-dependent).
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: MBO Partners estimate ~72.9M Americans working independently in 2025 (broad definition).
Freelance/independent knowledge work continues to expand materially; definitions vary by survey.

cases.claim: AI is an emerging (still minority) stated driver of US job cuts and is reshaping entry-level demand.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Job-cut reports track instances where employers cite AI as a driver; present but not dominant.
Coverage of bootcamp/downstream hiring notes weakening junior-market outcomes and hiring shifts (incl. AI impacts).

cases.claim: Coding bootcamp graduates have 90% employment rates (as a general market-wide claim).
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Reuters reports sharply lower placed-in-field outcomes for some bootcamp cohorts (far from 90%).
CIRR audited outcomes vary widely by program/cohort; inconsistent with blanket 90% claim.

cases.claim: H1B workers depress wages for domestic tech workers (overall effect).
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: EPI argues prevailing-wage compliance and wage setting can enable underpayment in some cases.
Richmond Fed notes H-1B workers are often high-skill/high-paid; effects depend on occupation/market.

cases.claim: Recent large trials found no productivity decline with a four-day work week (when work is redesigned, not compressed).
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Multi-country trial coverage reports improved wellbeing and maintained outcomes in participating firms.
UK pilot reporting: many firms maintained the model; productivity not broadly reported as declining.

cases.claim: Over 50% of US workers are 'quiet quitting'.
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: Gallup global: 21% engaged, 62% not engaged, 17% actively disengaged (engagement ≠ 'quiet quitting' and not US-only).
Definitions vary; engagement metrics don’t map cleanly to 'quiet quitting' behavior; direct US 50%+ claim hard to validate.

cases.claim: Tech hiring and demand for digital talent stayed resilient into 2025 across the US and UK, with AI-weighted roles expanding fastest.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: UK tech workforce reporting shows continued demand and large workforce scale into 2025.
AI mentions in job postings hit record highs (share-based surge).

cases.claim: Tech worker unionization doubled in 2025 (vs 2024) across the US and Europe.
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: BLS union data is broad; isolating 'tech worker unionization' across US+EU with consistent baselines is difficult.
Public reporting highlights isolated efforts rather than sector-wide doubling; standardized cross-region proof is limited.

cases.claim: Women remain underrepresented in computing/tech roles, and AI exposure/displacement risk can disproportionately affect women in some markets.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: US computing participation statistics show persistent underrepresentation across multiple measures.
UK-focused analysis suggests women are more represented in roles with higher AI-displacement exposure (distributional risk).

cases.claim: Freelance developers earn 50% more per hour than salaried peers (net of downtime and benefits).
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Independent-work research emphasizes accounting for unpaid time, taxes, and benefits; blanket +50% net premium not supported.
Freelancing is growing, but sources do not validate a universal +50% hourly premium net of costs.

cases.claim: Tech worker burnout remained very high into 2025 (majority reporting symptoms in surveys).
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Survey-based reporting indicates high burnout prevalence among tech workers across sampled populations.
Germany labor-market reporting flags burnout/overload concerns remaining salient into 2025.

cases.claim: Average tech tenure dropped below 2 years in 2025 across the US and Europe.
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: Tenure metrics differ (median vs mean; company vs occupation); cross-region 2025 'below 2 years' is not consistently substantiated.
Layoffs and volatility distort short-term tenure measures; clean 2025 sector-wide confirmation is limited.

cases.claim: AI-weighted job demand surged into 2025 (share of postings/titles rising), but '300% in 2025' is not reliably supported across markets.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: AI mentions in job ads reached record highs (strong share-based growth).
Europe tech hiring dataset shows rapid jump in AI job-title share in early 2025 (share-based, not absolute 300% claim).

cases.claim: Policy uncertainty around high-cost visas can accelerate offshoring and expansion of India-based Global Capability Centers (GCCs), including from Europe and the US.
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Reuters reports visa curbs prompting firms to consider shifting more work to India; GCC expansion used to hedge uncertainty.
Report cites 130+ UK firms operating 250+ GCCs in India employing 200,000+ professionals (UK→India GCC footprint).
